thread.title: Gloucester sheriff candidate convicted of weapons charge in 2011
thread.title_full: Gloucester sheriff candidate convicted of weapons charge in 2011

author: Frances Hubbard
title: Gloucester sheriff candidate convicted of weapons charge in 2011
text:
Gloucester sheriff candidate convicted of weapons charge in 2011 Gloucester sheriff candidate Clarence Bowser Kaitlin McKeown / Daily Press Gloucester sheriff candidate Clarence Bowser speaks with the Daily Press editorial board on Thursday, October 10. Gloucester sheriff candidate Clarence Bowser speaks with the Daily Press editorial board on Thursday, October 10. (Kaitlin McKeown / Daily Press) Frances Hubbard Contact Reporter fhubbard@dailypress.com "I don't have any regrets or any hard feelings cause I believe in the truth and the truth will come out." 
A candidate for Gloucester County sheriff was convicted on a charge of brandishing a firearm in 2011 after he pulled a gun from a holster when a deputy attempted to serve him with an arrest warrant. 
Clarence M. Bowser, 66, said he has no regrets following the incident on July 20, 2010, that resulted in a standoff between him and deputies at his home. In addition to the firearms charge, he was also convicted of obstruction of justice. 
Bowser has run for Gloucester sheriff three times and is a former county deputy. He is running against Sheriff Darrell Warren in the November election. 
"It was a bogus charge. I have nothing to hide," Bowser said in a phone interview on Wednesday. "I don't have any regrets or any hard feelings because I believe in the truth and the truth will come out. I'm a firm man and I stand my ground." 
Gloucester County deputies went to Bowser's home in the Woods Cross Roads area of the county on July 20, 2010, to serve a warrant for contempt of court, according to the incident report from the Gloucester County Sheriff's Office.
